title: Chapter 7 Bankruptcy - What will make a trustee ask for bank statements? Should I automatically include bank statements
question: in my filing?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,341 meeting of creditors,Bankruptcy trustee,Bankruptcy documents,Credit counseling,Credit,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
Actually, it depends on the local rules of court and the individual Trustee. LA is the Central District of California. Although you may not need to file your bank statements as part of your supporting documentation, I would highly recommend that you have them ready at your 341a Meeting of Creditors, in case the trustee asks.

Include 30 days prior to filing, the date of filing, and the day up to your hearing. Have this ready just in case. Otherwise, the Trustee can continue the hearing. Consult an attorney who is knowledgeable on the local rules and has established relationships with the Trustee panel.

Best of luck to you!

Some Trustees will ask for bank statements for every Debtor. However, most do not, unless they wish to verify information provided on the schedules.

As a rule, never provide anything unless it is required or as been specifically requested.

The trustees in the District of Oregon always ask debtors to bring bank statements to the 341 hearing.

You are not required to include bank statements when you file a Chapter 7 bankruptcy. In addition to the bankruptcy petition and schedules, you will need to file the pre-filing credit counseling certificate and payment advices with your bankruptcy filing. You might have to provide the Ch 7 trustee with copies of bank statements if they are requested. The trustee might ask for the bank statements if you are self-employed.
There is no need to automatically include bank statements. If you are self-employed, the Trustee may ask to see them to verify the gross receipts on your P&L.
